claim: If the study center had begun enrolling patients only after the year 2000, the proportion of female patients born after 1930 among female patients would have been at least 99%.
extra_info: female refers to Sex = 'F'; patient who were born after 1930 refers to year(Birthday) > '1930'; calculation = DIVIDE(COUNT(ID) where year(Birthday) > '1930' and SEX = 'F'), (COUNT(ID) where SEX = 'F')
reasoning: The claim is counterfactual — it asks about a hypothetical scenario ('If the study center had begun enrolling patients only after the year 2000'). The database records what actually happened, not what would have happened under different enrollment conditions. Counterfactual claims cannot be verified from historical data and must be classified as NOT ENOUGH INFO.

content.text:
This claim contains counterfactual language: "If the study center had begun enrolling patients only after the year 2000..." This describes a hypothetical scenario — what would have happened under different enrollment conditions — not what actually happened.

According to my instructions, counterfactual claims that describe "what if" scenarios cannot be verified from a database that only records what actually happened. They must always be classified as NOT ENOUGH INFO.
